title: Claudio Jara
text:
Claudio Miguel Jara Granados (born 6 May 1959) is a former <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a>n <a href="Association%20football">football</a> striker who played more than a decade for <a href="C.S.%20Herediano">Herediano</a> and participated in the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a> finals.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Heredia%2C%20Costa%20Rica">Heredia</a>, Jara began playing football with local side <a href="C.S.%20Herediano">Herediano</a>. He made his debut in 1982, and became Herediano's all-time leading goal-scorer, with 98 league goals during his 11 years with the club. He totalled 375 matches for the club. He spent 15 seasons playing in the <a href="Costa%20Rican%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Costa Rican Primera División</a> with Herediano, <a href="L.D.%20Alajuelense">Alajuelense</a>, <a href="Brujas%20F.C.">Guanacasteca</a> and <a href="Asociaci%C3%B3n%20Deportiva%20Carmelita">Carmelita</a>. In 1992, Jara left Herediano to sign with Alajuelense. A six-month spell with Colombian side <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Bucaramanga">Atlético Bucaramanga</a> followed.
In 1994, he returned to Heredia, but quickly moved to <a href="El%20Salvador">El Salvador</a> to play one season with <a href="Alianza%20F.C.">Alianza</a>. Next, he returned to Costa Rica and played for Guanacasteca and Carmelita, retiring from football after suffering a serious knee injury in 1996.
International career.
He was part of the <a href="Costa%20Rica%20national%20football%20team">national team</a> squad, that played in the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a> held in <a href="Italy">Italy</a> and featured in all four games played. The <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> made his debut for the "Ticos" in 1983 and collected 46 caps, scoring 11 goals.
He played his final international on December 17, 1994 against <a href="Saudi%20Arabia%20national%20football%20team">Saudi Arabia</a>.
Managerial career.
After he retired from playing football, Jara became a football coach. He was appointed manager of <a href="A.D.%20Sagrada%20Familia">Sagrada Familia</a> in January 2010. In December 2012 he resigned at <a href="C.S.%20Herediano">Herediano</a> after 4 months at the helm.
Personal life.
His brother <a href="Geovanny%20Jara">Geovanny Jara</a> played 422 matches for Herediano and also played for the national team.
